steps.title: Keep the area clean and dry.
steps.content: Keep the area clean and dry. Splash your raw skin with cool water and lightly apply a gentle, scent- and alcohol-free cleanser twice each day. Cleanse more often if you notice dirt or debris on the raw areas. Pat the area dry with a clean towel to prevent further irritation. This can clear away debris or bacteria and minimize your risk of infection. [1] X Research source Avoid scrubbing or rubbing the area too harshly, which can cause irritation.

steps.title: Apply a protective salve to raw areas.
steps.content: Apply a protective salve to raw areas. Dab on a thin layer of a protective cream, lotion or ointment that is gentle as well as scent- and alcohol-free. Use products including zinc oxide, petroleum jelly, or aloe on the raw skin and surrounding area. This may help protect your raw skin and soothe any irritation. Ask your pharmacist or doctor for the best type of protective layer for your raw skin. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Apply the ointment twice per day, or more as needed. Petroleum jelly can worsen seborrheic dermatitis, so avoid using it if you have this condition. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Cover raw areas with bandages.
steps.content: Cover raw areas with bandages. Select a non-stick or fabric bandage manufactured for sensitive skin. Apply your choice over any raw areas, securing adhesive edges to healthy skin. This can protect the area from contact with your hands or fingers, and extreme temperatures as well as irritants and bacteria, which minimize the risk of infection. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Sprinkle talc-free powder on raw skin.
steps.content: Sprinkle talc-free powder on raw skin. If your raw skin is a result of chafing (friction), apply a powder such as alum or cornstarch to the raw areas. Reapply the powder after showers or anytime your skin is moist. This can whisk away moisture from your skin and prevent further irritation. It may also promote healing by preventing friction. Talcum powder has been tentatively linked to cancer when used on genital areas, so avoid these products until further studies have been conducted. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Cancer Society Nonprofit devoted to promoting cancer research, education, and support Go to source

steps.title: Keep raw skin out of the sun.
steps.content: Keep raw skin out of the sun . To allow your skin to heal and protect it from further damage, keep raw skin out of the sun. Avoid the sun during peak hours, like from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Wear clothing with long sleeves and pants as well a sun hat. Apply a water-resistant, broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher (only on intact, non-irritated skin) if you do need to be outdoors. [6] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Avoid scratching itchy skin.
steps.content: Avoid scratching itchy skin. Scratching can lead to infection, scars, and in severe cases, thickening of the skin. Take an over-the-counter antihistamine or apply a cortisone cream to the skin if it is very itchy or if it is the result of an allergic reaction. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Draw a warm oatmeal bath.
steps.content: Draw a warm oatmeal bath. Fill your tub with warm water to a level that reaches your raw skin. Sprinkle the bathwater with colloidal oatmeal, which is a finely ground oatmeal specifically made for the bathtub. Soak in the oatmeal and warm water for 5-10 minutes. Then pat your skin dry and apply a moisturizer. This may soothe raw skin and promote healing. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Use uncooked oatmeal if you cannot find colloidal oatmeal.

steps.title: Wear loose, cotton clothing.
steps.content: Wear loose, cotton clothing. While your skin is healing, put on loose clothing made of a smooth and breathable fabric such as lightweight cotton. This can prevent further irritation of raw skin. It also increases airflow to promote healing. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Avoid wearing several layers of clothing. Loosen your clothing to prevent irritation and excess moisture.

steps.title: Avoid irritants or allergens.
steps.content: Avoid irritants or allergens. Minimize or avoid potentially irritating products or allergens. Use products that are labeled scent-, fragrance-, and dye-free. This may help speed healing and prevent further irritation. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Seek medical attention if your skin doesn’t heal.
steps.content: Seek medical attention if your skin doesn’t heal. Even with home care, your raw skin may not heal. Tell your doctor when you noticed the raw skin and what home treatment you’ve done. They can diagnose potential causes or conditions and get you prompt and proper treatment. See a doctor if your raw skin: Is so painful that you lose sleep or get distracted from your daily routine Becomes painful Appears infected Won’t heal with self-care

steps.title: Look for a red rash to identify a yeast or bacterial infection.
steps.content: Look for a red rash to identify a yeast or bacterial infection. Examine your raw skin and the affected area around it for a red, inflamed, or itchy rash. These marks scattered across your skin can indicate a bacterial or yeast infection. If you suspect a bacterial or yeast infection, see your doctor, who can diagnose the problem. [11] X Research source They may suggest better hygiene to clear up the area and prevent future outbreaks. For more severe cases, the doctor will prescribe a prescription medication to soothe and heal the area. If you are taking antibiotics , this may cause a yeast infection that leads to raw skin. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Watch for friction flare-ups in areas that rub fabric.
steps.content: Watch for friction flare-ups in areas that rub fabric. Notice if the areas of your skin that are raw are on your thighs, groin, underarms or nipples. These may be the result of friction from wearing tight clothing, shoes, or skin rubbing on skin. Soothe these areas with a thin layer of protective salve. This can also prevent future raw skin from friction. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Rule out products gradually to identify irritants.
steps.content: Rule out products gradually to identify irritants. Review any products that touch your skin including your skincare, detergents, or topical medications. Gradually remove individual products from your routine until you figure out which one is causing the raw skin. Discontinue use of the product to see if your skin heals or calms down. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Check exposure to allergens.
steps.content: Check exposure to allergens. See if your raw skin is on an area exposed to or touched by potential allergens such as plants, detergents, food, or animals. This can indicate an allergic reaction that may heal by discontinuing use or avoiding the allergen. Taking an oral over-the-counter antihistamine may relieve pain and inflammation and promote healing. [15] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source An allergic rash can happen in conjunction with raw skin caused by irritants. [16] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Keep the raw area dry if you have intertrigo.
steps.content: Keep the raw area dry if you have intertrigo. Intertrigo is a rash that forms between folds of skin. Examine your raw skin for mirroring on either side, and notice if the skin also appears moist, thin, or like it has lost several layers, all of which can indicate intertrigo. Keep the area dry by exposing it to air or dabbing a towel on it to promote healing. [17] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Intertrigo rashes can present on parts of the body exposed to heat or moisture. You should stay cool and avoid sun exposure to prevent further irritation.

steps.title: Examine skin for seborrheic scales.
steps.content: Examine skin for seborrheic scales. Check your raw skin for scales or rough patches. If the raw skin is greasy skin and has yellowish scales, you may have seborrheic dermatitis. [18] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source This may also be atopic dermatitis (eczema) in rare cases. See your doctor for a definitive diagnosis. [19] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Your doctor can suggest the most appropriate treatment, such as light therapy or antifungal medication, to soothe and heal your raw skin. This type of raw skin generally appears on the scalp, face, upper chest, and back. Avoid using petroleum jelly if you have seborrheic dermatitis, as it can worsen the condition. [20] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Reduce your stress.
steps.content: Reduce your stress. Stress can affect the body’s immune system, which can create skin issues like acne and eczema. [21] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Reduce your stress level by eating healthy, getting enough sleep, and exercising regularly. You can also make time for things you enjoy and participate in calming activities like yoga .
